citation.article-title: Marinitoga piezophila sp. nov., a rod-shaped, thermo-piezophilic bacterium isolated under high hydrostatic pressure from a deep-sea hydrothermal vent.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Marinitoga piezophila sp. nov.
Marinitoga piezophila (pie.zo'phi.la. Gr. v. piezo to press; Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. fem. adj. piezophila referring to its best growth under pressure)
The cells are rod-shaped with a sheath-like outer structure, motile with polar flagella, and stain Gramnegative.
Under optimal conditions, cells appear as short rods (1-1.5 μm longx0.5 μm wide), singly or in short chains of fewer than five cells.
On the other hand, they show cellular deformations, becoming twisted and elongated when they are cultivated at decreased pressures.
Grows optimally at 3% (w/v) NaCl and pH 6.0.
Growth occurs at 40-75°C, the optimum growth temperature being 65°C.
Piezophile at its growth temperature range, optimum growth occurring at 40 MPa.
Optimal doubling time (at 65°C and 40 MPa) is 21 min; maximum cell yield in vials is 5.6x108 cells ml8.
Grows on complex organic compounds and several carbohydrates in the presence of yeast extract.
L-Cystine and elemental sulfur greatly enhance growth but are not absolutely required.
The G+C content of the genomic DNA is 29±1 mol%.
The 16S rDNA gene sequence similarity to Marinitoga camini is 94%.
Isolated from a hydrothermal vent sample, under 30 MPa hydrostatic pressure at 65°C, from the East-Pacific Ridge, 13° N, at a depth of 2630 m.
The type strain is strain KA3T (=DSM 14283T=JCM11233T).
The GenBank accession number for the 16S rDNA sequence of the type strain is AF326121.
